_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This executive summary provides a brief overview of the Risk Management Program (RMP) and the associated policies at the Moffat Water Treatment Plant, one of several facilities owned and operated by Denver Water.



Prevention and Response Policies



Denver Water believes that it is important to provide a safe workplace to its employees and minimize the impact of its operations on the surrounding community and the environment.  Accordingly, Denver Water has developed proactive safety and environmental programs, which are reliant upon active employee participation and management leadership and support.  This same proactive philosophy was employed in the development and implementation of the Moffat Water Treatment Plant RMP for the chlorine system.  



The RMP prevention program is arguably the most important element of the rule.  Its program elements require the active participation of facility employees and management in conducting activities aimed at preventing accidental releases of regulated chemicals.  If prevention activities could be completely successful, there would be no need for emergency response activities, since no releases would occur.  Accordingly, a well-developed and properly-implemented prevention program will lower the possibility of an accidental release and minimize the consequences of a release should one occur.



Denver Water takes an active role in preventing accidental releases at all of its facilities by ensuring that its employees are well-informed regarding the hazards associated with the regulated processes (e.g., chlorine at the Moffat Water Treatment Plant) and actively participated in comprehensive hazard analyses.  The systems employees are properly trained in the safe operation of the covered process and the safe handling of treatment chemicals.  They are aided in this work by complete, understandable system operating procedures.



Denver Water management understands its duty to provide a safe working environment and to take mea

sures to prevent accidents that may have an impact on the surrounding community.  This understanding is reflected in procedures described and referenced in the Moffat Water Treatment Plant RMP procedures and policies.



As for emergency response, Denver Water has established procedures for emergency response and notification when necessary.  Moffat employees are responsible for providing initial response to a release of chlorine.  Releases contained within the plant facilities will be remedied by plant personnel and equipment, in accordance with OSHAs Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Standard (29 CFR 1910.120).  Releases affecting (or with the potential to affect) areas outside the facility will require outside assistance, and local emergency response entities will be solicited for emergency response support.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Moffat Water Treatment Plant is located at 10901 West 20th Avenue in Lakewood, Colorado.  



The facility provides treated drinking water for Denver Water customers.  Facility influent consists of flows from Ralston Reservoir and uses conventional water treatment technologies to remove solids, and pathogens (chemical treatment, flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration).  The water is further treated by the addition of chlorine, aqueous ammonia, and sodium hydroxide.  The chlorine (Cl2) is stored on site in enclosed buidlings.



The maximum intended inventory of chlorine at the Moffat Water Treatment Plant is 48,000 pounds (24 one-ton containers).  Therefore, the Plant is regulated under the RMP rule due to the volume of chlorine stored and used at the facility.



Prevention Steps for Chlorine



The prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps are described in detail in the RMP Management System document and the RMP Share Point site. The prevention programs include the following elements:

- Safety Information, which has been collated into the RMP Share Point si

te.

- Hazard Reviews - Every 5-years a knowledgeable group of employees conducts the Hazard Review to ensure consideration is given to possible events that may cause chlorine leaks. In addition, major changes generate an updated hazard review.

- Operating procedures for applicable processes are maintained on the RMP Share Point site.

- Training for all personnel involved in the operation and maintenance of the chlorine system.

- Incident investigation procedures for the investigation of any catastrophic (or potentially catastrophic) incident associated with the chlorine system, using the Denver Water Incident Investigation Report procedures.

- Compliance audits to be conducted at least once every three years to ensure the continued compliance of the Plant's RMP programs.



In addition to these elements, the chlorine storage room at the Moffat Water Treatment Plant is equipped with a chlorine scrubber, which will evacuate chlorine-laden air from the chlorine storage and feed areas, reducing the concentration of chlorine gas to safe levels prior to discharge to the atmosphere.  The scrubber will pull vapors out of both the chlorine storage and feed rooms.  An exhaust fan pulls air into the scrubber exposing it to neutralization prior to discharge to the exhaust stack.  The scrubber has an exhaust detector to monitor the chlorine concentration in the discharge stack. Dampers allow for makeup air to enter the chlorine storage and feed rooms, replacing air that is pulled through the scrubber.  The scrubber's discharge stack is curved downward at its exhaust point to prevent water from getting in.  The end of this vent stack is 6 feet above the roofline.  Overall scrubber removal efficiency is 99+%, with an estimated chlorine concentration < 5 ppm going out the stack.  



The chlorine storage room has leak detection.  There is also leak detection in the chlorine injector/feed room. An alarm of 4 ppm or greater at any of these four leak detectors will activate the s

crubber.  They will also trigger red, flashing alarm beacons, audible alarms (local and over the plant intercom system), and control room alarms to warn other personnel.  Leak detectors will be calibrated for a range of 0-30 ppm, with digital chlorine level readout locally, outside of the room, and in the control room.  The system also closes seven of the eight emergency shutoff valves on the on-line group of ton containers, and closes all emergency shutoff valves on the remaining two off-line groups of ton containers.



The chlorine scrubber will be maintained and tested on a regular basis to ensure proper operation during a chlorine release event.



Accident History



There have been no releases of hazardous air pollutants from the Moffat Water Treatment Plant with off-site consequences during the past five years. The chlorine system was installed in 2000, with construction completed in 2000. The system incorporates up-to-date safety measures to help prevent releases.



Emergency Response Program



Denver Water has established procedures for emergency response and notification when necessary.  Moffat Plant employees are responsible for providing initial response to a release of chlorine.  Releases contained within the plant facilities will be remedied by Plant personnel and equipment, in accordance with OSHAs Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) Standard (29 CFR 1910.120).  Releases affecting (or with the potential to affect) areas outside the facility will require outside assistance, and local emergency response entities (West Metro Fire Protection District and Hazardous Materials Response Team) will be solicited for emergency response support.



Planned Changes for Improved Safety



Ideas for changes to improve will be actively sought from employees.  Employee meetings that focus on safety issues will be held regularly at the Moffat Water Treatment Plant Plant.  Employees will be encouraged and trained to recognize hazards and to p

resent ides to eliminate them or to minimize the potential consequences of those hazards.



As part of the development of the Moffat Water Treatment Plant RMP program, a hazard review was conducted with key employees to meet the prevention program requirements.  The Hazard Analysis is reviewed and recommendations made for the purpose of improving safety and preventing accidental chemical releases are evaluated.  Each recommendation has been considered for implementation.  Though not all recommendations may be implemented, all have been considered.  The exercise and HAZWOPER training have provided affected employees with a heightened awareness of safety issues related to the covered processes.
